title: 103_hr82
content: Restoration of deduction for interest on educational loans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 restores the deduction for interest on qualified educational loans, defining such loans as indebtedness provided through certain guarantee programs. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is restored under the amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Qualified educational loans are defined as indebtedness provided through specific guarantee programs or by certain organizations exempt from tax. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is restored under the amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amount of interest deductible is reduced based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year. The taxpayer's adjusted gross income determines the deduction for interest on qualified educational loans. The applicable dollar amount and phaseout range vary based on filing status. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The applicable dollar amount is $30,000, and in some cases, it may be zero. The deduction is only allowable for the first 48 months of repayment, and it applies to qualified educational expenses such as tuition and related expenses for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents. The tax deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is based on adjusted gross income. The deduction applies to tuition and related expenses for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents attending an educational institution. The deduction amount is subject to adjustment for inflation. In 1994, the $40,000 and $60,000 amounts in subparagraph (B) will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for that year. Amounts will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50 if not already a multiple. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1993, for loans with the first required payment due after that date. The amount will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50, or the next highest multiple if it is already a multiple of $25.
